civilRights.name: Civil Rights
civilRights.description: Less state constraint ↔ More state constraint

typeDescriptions.lgmp: Liberty-oriented, globally-integrated market progressives who emphasize pragmatic growth and innovation.
typeDescriptions.agmp: Authority-leaning technocrats who favor global markets but with significant state oversight and control.
typeDescriptions.lgmt: Liberty-minded market builders with traditional values, emphasizing free enterprise and cultural preservation.
typeDescriptions.agmt: Paternalistic developers who blend market mechanisms with traditional values under state guidance.
typeDescriptions.lgsp: Progressive internationalists combining social redistribution with global integration and civil liberties.
typeDescriptions.agsp: State-managed globalists who favor international redistribution with stronger government control.
typeDescriptions.lgst: Conservative diplomats balancing global engagement with traditional values and civil liberties.
typeDescriptions.agst: Hierarchical globalists combining international social policy with authoritarian governance structures.
typeDescriptions.lnsp: Democratic socialists emphasizing national social programs while protecting civil liberties.
typeDescriptions.ansp: State socialists who favor strong national redistribution under centralized authority.
typeDescriptions.lnst: Communitarian social conservatives blending national solidarity with traditional values and some liberty.
typeDescriptions.anst: National authoritarians combining closed borders, state redistribution, and traditional social control.
typeDescriptions.lnmp: Libertarian nationalists who favor national sovereignty, free markets, and minimal government.
typeDescriptions.anmp: Authoritarian nationalists emphasizing strong state control with market-oriented national economics.
typeDescriptions.lnmt: Traditional localists valuing community-based markets, national identity, and cultural preservation.
typeDescriptions.anmt: Authoritarian traditionalists combining strong state power, national markets, and traditional values.

scoringMethodology: Scores represent positions on four independent axes. Call signs are generated by selecting the letter corresponding to each axis position (L/A for Civil Rights, G/N for Openness, M/S for Redistribution, P/T for Ethics). Intensity (1-3) reflects strength of position.

lgmp.examples: Ezra Klein, Matt Yglesias, Progress Studies advocates, pragmatic YIMBYs, growth-oriented progressives

agmp.examples: Singapore model, authoritarian capitalism with progressive values, technocratic governance

lgmt.examples: Libertarian traditionalists, free-market conservatives with cultural preservation focus

agmt.examples: Paternalistic conservatives, guided capitalism with traditional values

lgsp.examples: Bernie Sanders, AOC, progressive internationalists, democratic socialists

agsp.examples: China, managed global redistribution with state control

lgst.examples: Traditional internationalists, globally-engaged social democrats with conservative values

agst.examples: Authoritarian welfare states with traditional values, hierarchical global engagement

lnsp.examples: National progressives, left-wing populists emphasizing sovereignty and social programs

lnst.examples: Communitarian conservatives, national solidarity with traditional values

anst.examples: National Bolshevism, authoritarian nationalist socialism with traditional control

lnmp.examples: Libertarian nationalists, free markets with national sovereignty and progressive values

anmp.examples: Viktor Orbán, authoritarian market nationalism with progressive rhetoric

lnmt.examples: Rod Dreher, localist conservatives, traditional market nationalism

anmt.examples: MAGA movement, Trump, authoritarian national conservatism
